title: Theresa May leads praise for Donald Trump and his vow to secure rapid UK-US trade deal
text:
Theresa May leads praise for Donald Trump and his vow to secure rapid UK-US trade deal Theresa May leads praise for Donald Trump and his vow to secure rapid UK-US trade deal THERESA May led senior politicians today in welcoming Donald Trump’s vow to secure a rapid free trade deal with the UK. PUBLISHED: 17:37, Mon, Jan 16, 2017 | UPDATED: 18:06, Mon, Jan 16, 2017 
The businessman, who will be sworn in as American President on Friday, said he would work hard to get an agreement done “quickly” and that Brexit would be “a great thing”. 
He also looked forward to meeting Prime Minister May soon after he takes office. 
The PM’s official spokeswoman told reporters: “We welcome the commitment from the President-elect to engage with the UK on this, to work together to agree a deal quickly. Related articles EU warns Britain there can be NO trade talks with US until after Brexi 
"That highlights one of the opportunities of the UK leaving the EU. 
“We welcome the enthusiasm and energy the president-elect and his team are showing for engaging with the UK.” 
Mrs May’s expected spring visit to Washington would be a chance for “early discussions” on a UK-US trade deal. GETTY Prime Minister Theresa May has welcomed President-elect Donald Trump's vow to secure a trade deal 
But while it was possible to hold “scoping discussions” before Britain actually leaves the European Union on how to reduce trade barriers, the UK would respect EU rules which ban members from signing their own agreements with other countries until they formally leave the bloc, stressed the spokeswoman. We welcome the commitment from the President-elect to engage with the UK on this Theresa May's spokeswoman 
Mr Trump’s comments came in interview with Tory MP, former minister and journalist Michael Gove, a leader of the successful Vote Leave campaign, and German newspaper Bild. 
Asked if it would be possible to get a US-UK trade deal quite quickly, the President-elect said: “Absolutely - very quickly. 
“I’m a big fan of the UK. We’re gonna work very hard to get it done quickly and done properly - good for both sides.” 
Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson , who last week visited the US for talks with leading Trump advisers , said: “I think it’s very good news that the United States of America want to do a good free trade deal with us and wants to do it very fast and it’s great to hear that from President-elect Donald Trump. 
“Clearly it will have to be a deal that is very much in the interests of both sides but I have no doubt that it will be.” 
Mr Gove told broadcasters: “I think the President-elect wants to have something signature-ready at the earliest possible opportunity.” GETTY Mrs May's spokeswoman said it highlighted the opportunities of the UK leaving the EU 
Mr Trump would want a “win-win deal” and was “enthusiastic” about Brexit , he said, adding: “He stressed that he believed the EU would potentially break up in the future and that other countries would leave. 
"So in a sense he is both emotionally and financially invested in it.” 
The offer of a US trade deal would strengthen Mrs May’s hand in her Brexit negotiations with Brussels, Mr Gove believed. GETTY Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was 'great' to hear from Mr Trump 
“The EU until now has been assumed to have a better hand to play, but the Prime Minister we now see has actually cards in her hand, including from candidate Trump, which will enable her, I think, to secure a better deal.” 
The MP said he had found Mr Trump to be “warmer” in person than he had expected. 
Mr Trump should be viewed as a businessman: “The important thing about any world leader dealing with Donald Trump is to think ‘how can I get a deal that suits us both’.” 
His trade deal comments should also be regarded as “sincere”. EUROSCEPTICISM: Which are the most eurosceptic countries? Mon, January 16, 2017 EUROSCEPTICISM, meaning criticism of the European Union (EU). Rising disenchantment with the dealings of EU is not just confined to the UK... Play slideshow 1 of 8 
But Mr Trump also clearly had a “soft spot” for Britain generally and in particular for his late mother’s birthplace of Scotland, said Mr Gove. 
“He wants to make sure that America and Britain have a strong business relationship but he also wants to make sure that Britain flourishes because we have got a special place in his heart.” 
Mr Gove believed Mr Trump was an “admirer” of Mrs May and wanted the strongest possible relationship between their two countries. 
The President-elect also felt “a sort of sense of ownership of our decision to leave the EU because he predicted it and he was one of the few international figures to back our leaving the EU. GETTY Michael Gove believes a US trade deal will strengthen the PM's hand in Brexit negotiations 
“Now he says that he wants to make a success of it. He thinks we are ‘doing great’, as he said in the interview. 
"That goodwill, I think, will extend into making sure that we can do all the preparatory work at the earliest possible stage in order to get the best possible deal.” 
Former UK Independence Party leader Nigel Farage, who was among the first foreign politicians to meet Mr Trump after his shock election win and who will be in Washington for the inauguration, Tweeted that the interview contained “no surprises” but showed there were “serious opportunities” to be had with the arrival of the new President. GETTY Mr Trump will be sworn in as American President on Friday 
Former Bill Clinton advisor Albert Scardino warned Mr Trump would find it harder to get things done as President than as a businessman - and that the UK-US trade deal may be delayed by the need to secure the American Senate’s approval. 
Mr Trump also said he believed other countries would follow Britain out of the EU, saying: “People, countries want their own identity ...” 
But EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said: “I’m not worried. I think this idea that Brexit is going to be contagious is a fantasy - a bad fantasy. Brexit is not a great thing.” Related articles
